title: The left smells blood after shocking Democratic primary result
description:
Progressives are feeling newly emboldened by the stronger-than-expected showing of the left-wing outsider in a New Jersey congressional primary on Thursday.

Why it matters: There are dozens of House races like this across the country where at least one left-wing insurgent is vying either to win an open seat or topple an establishment House Democratic incumbent.

  • "This is a clear sign that the Democratic electorate is desperate to elect new leaders ‚Äî like the dozen of working class champions we're supporting in primaries this cycle," Justice Democrats spokesperson Usamah Andrabi told Axios.
  • Rep. Ro Khanna (D-Calif.) said the New Jersey result "shows that the progressive wing... is ascendant and consistent with the base of the party."

Driving the news: The 13-candidate Democratic primary to replace now-Gov. Mikie Sherrill in New Jersey's 11th congressional district ended in a dead heat between progressive organizer Analilia Mejia and former Rep. Tom Malinowski.

  • With several thousand provisional and late mail-in still to be counted as of Friday, Mejia led Malinowski by 500 votes, 28.75% to 27.97%, according to the Associated Press.
  • Mejia trailed many of her opponents in fundraising, bringing in just $420,000 to Malinowski's $1.2 million.

The intrigue: AIPAC spent over $2 million against Malinowski ‚Äî a mainstream Democrat who had the group's support in the past ‚Äî for his willingness to condition aid to Israel.

  • The group reportedly favored former Lt. Gov. Tahesha Way, who had support from parts of the Democratic Party establishment.
  • Observers say that created an opening for Mejia, the most prominent progressive in the race, who was endorsed by Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.), Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-N.Y.) and the Progressive Caucus.
  • "AIPAC affiliated groups spent millions," noted one centrist House Democrat when asked about the result. "Wouldn't have even happened without that."

What we're hearing: A senior House Democrat, asked if members were freaking out about their own primaries in the wake of the shock result, told Axios, simply, "Yes."

  • "I definitely think this points to progressive anti-establishment energy," acknowledged a third House Democrat, a moderate in a swing-district.
  • Still, that lawmaker argued that too many moderate candidates split votes and endorsements and that "if [the] establishment and money all got behind one candidate like what normally happens," Mejia may not have won.

Zoom in: Other Democrats said the result is more of a referendum on AIPAC money than a true barometer of where the energy is in the primary electorate right now.

  • Rep. Mark Pocan (D-Wisc.), a vocal AIPAC critic, told Axios this election was the "first real test of their money and it failed miserably," adding, "My advice to anyone is avoid their support. It could cost you mightily."
  • Several lawmakers also pointed to the splintered field of establishment-aligned candidates, with others noting that Malinowski had faced hits of carpetbagging from his former district.

Zoom out: There are plenty of other primaries this year that will demonstrate whether this race is a fluke or a sign of things to come.

  • Several older, establishment-aligned House Democrats such as Reps. Ed Case (D-Hawaii), Stephen Lynch (D-Mass.) and Doris Matsui (D-Calif.) are facing primary challengers who have raised serious sums.
  • Numerous open primaries in deep blue districts also feature prominent progressive candidates, such as Kat Abughazaleh in Illinois' 9th district.

The bottom line: "It was true in 2025 and will be true in 2026: The establishment is not unbeatable - they have only gone unchallenged," said Amanda Litman, the co-founder of Run For Something.

  • "Voters are pissed: They want change and they want leaders who can credibly make the case that they'll fight like hell. Money matters ‚Äî but voters' fury matters more."

Editor's note: This story has been updated with additional reporting.

title: Members of Congress will have access to unredacted Epstein files
description:
The Justice Department will let members of Congress view unredacted copies of the more than 3 million documents related to Jeffrey Epstein that have been publicly released, according to a letter obtained by Axios.

Why it matters: Democrats have argued that the DOJ is skirting its statutory requirements under the Epstein Transparency Act by withholding millions of documents and heavily redacting some of the files they did release.

  • House Judiciary Committee ranking member Jamie Raskin (D-Md.) sent a letter to the DOJ last week requesting a review of the "complete unredacted Epstein files."
  • "We seek to ensure that your redactions comply with the Act's requirement that materials be withheld only in narrow circumstances, such as protecting victims' personally identifiable information, and not on the basis of "embarrassment, reputational harm, or political sensitivity, including to any government official, public figure, or foreign dignitary,'" Raskin wrote.

Driving the news: House members and senators will be given access to unredacted copies of the files starting on Feb. 9, assistant attorney general Patrick Davis wrote in a letter to members of Congress.

  • The documents will be available on computers in a reading room at the DOJ building in Washington, D.C., from 9am to 6pm, Monday through Friday, Davis continued.
  • Members must give at least 24 hours' notice and cannot bring in electronic devices, though they are permitted to take notes.
  • The letter was first reported by NBC News.

What they're saying: The review is "in keeping with the Department of Justice's commitment to maximum transparency regarding our compliance with the Epstein Files Transparency Act," Davis said.

  • "We are confident that this review will further demonstrate the Department's good faith work to appropriately process an enormous volume of documents in a very short time."

title: My Review of Malley‚Äôs Chocolates
description:
As I leave Malley‚Äôs and watch the familiar sign diminish behind me, I feel a peculiar mixture of privilege and loss. To live in a city where such chocolate exists is a small fortune. To recognize that one cannot belong to it entirely is a quieter sorrow, a grief that must settle without spectacle. For […]

The post My Review of Malley‚Äôs Chocolates appeared first on Cleveland Scene.
content:
As I leave Malley‚Äôs and watch the familiar sign diminish behind me, I feel a peculiar mixture of privilege and loss. To live in a city where such chocolate exists is a small fortune. To recognize that one cannot belong to it entirely is a quieter sorrow, a grief that must settle without spectacle.

For many years my relationship with chocolate was uncomplicated. International brands filled ordinary spaces. Grocery lines, airport stores, conference snack tables. They were agreeable, reliable, designed to satisfy without asking anything in return. I accepted them as one accepts certain customs: useful, unquestioned, sufficient.

Malley‚Äôs existed in the background of my life long before I allowed myself to approach it closely. I knew its reputation. I remembered flavors that lingered longer than conversation. Textures that resisted quick conclusions. And surprisingly, while elegant and transformative, Malley‚Äôs is unassuming, humble, easy to access. But visiting the store itself felt like crossing an invisible boundary; stepping into a more particular world, one that invited attention rather than casual consumption. I arrived with a list of goals, gifts for others, but found myself mentally drafting a pros-and-cons table for personal consumption instead.

On a gray February afternoon, I entered with the intention of choosing a single elegant gift. The displays were arranged with calm assurance. Nothing felt extraneous. Each seemed to reveal a preference I had not yet admitted to myself. I experienced an unexpected sense of recognition, as though encountering something familiar yet newly significant.

The temptation was not excess but intimacy. The feeling that one could understand every variety, explore every possibility. For a brief moment I imagined a life organized entirely around Malley‚Äôs, a life of uninterrupted sweetness. Reason intervened quickly: health, balance, the ordinary structures that sustain a respectable existence.

Still, I lingered longer than intended. My fingertips moved across the displays with a care that surprised me. A quiet awareness traveled upward; physical, unmistakable, and difficult to justify. Language softened; time shifted. Eventually I left, not because desire faded but because I understood that certain experiences deepen when approached with restraint. I wondered if the clerk had ever witnessed someone tallying the calories of longing in real time.

In the weeks that followed, I returned to familiar routines. Commercial chocolate resumed its modest place in daily life, a reminder of equilibrium. Yet something had changed internally. The knowledge of Malley‚Äôs introduced a subtle tension. A private awareness that these vivid flavors existed.

Distance became an act of preservation. Occasional visits. Small boxes. Careful choices as if I were training for a disciplined life of chocolate austerity. The longing did not disappear; it matured into a quiet appreciation shaped by boundaries.

Some pleasures must remain partially unrealized to retain their meaning. Not because they are forbidden outright, but because their intensity would disrupt the fragile architecture of ordinary days. They remain part of the landscape: familiar, luminous, approached with gratitude and caution.

As the Malley‚Äôs sign disappears completely from view, I feel neither regret nor triumph. Only the calm recognition that certain attachments are sustained best through respectful distance. Known, cherished, and never allowed to overtake the life that surrounds them. A small box sits in the passenger seat, a quiet monument, and only later do I notice my vision blur slightly, as though the winter air had followed me into the car. I tell myself that the occasional Malley‚Äôs indulgence is sophisticated research, trusting my insulin to understand.

title: Double D‚Äôs Honky Tonk and Smokehouse to Open in Willoughby
description:
‚ÄúThis concept has been brewing for 17 years, but it took a 12-year hiatus while I was with Shake Shack,‚Äù says Dustin Dykstra. And now that Dykstra has a space to go with the concept, he is ‚Äúhitting the ground running.‚Äù The longtime hospitality pro has signed a lease for one of the most prominent […]

The post Double D‚Äôs Honky Tonk and Smokehouse to Open in Willoughby appeared first on Cleveland Scene.
content:
‚ÄúThis concept has been brewing for 17 years, but it took a 12-year hiatus while I was with Shake Shack,‚Äù says Dustin Dykstra.

And now that Dykstra has a space to go with the concept, he is ‚Äúhitting the ground running.‚Äù The longtime hospitality pro has signed a lease for one of the most prominent commercial properties in Willoughby, formerly home to Hola Tacos and Brim Kitchen (3941 Erie St.). Sometime this spring, he will open Double D‚Äôs Honky Tonk and Smokehouse.

Dykstra is a Northeast Ohio native, but he left home to pursue a career in hospitality. For more than a decade he has worked for the Shake Shack restaurant chain. As area director, he oversaw operations at a dozen different locations in multiple states. More importantly, he worked for Danny Meyer, one of the most respected names in hospitality.

‚ÄúI consider myself unbelievably lucky to have worked for him,‚Äù says Dykstra. ‚ÄúI got the playbook on how to do it right and intentional and with fiscal discipline, which is worth its weight in gold.‚Äù

The Brim/Hola property is an 8,000-square-foot, two-level building with massive windows, tall ceilings and exposed rafters. The upper level boasts a walkout patio with expansive views. Constructed in 2016, the property is in fine form, says Dykstra, needing only minor aesthetic work to fit his concept.

‚ÄúThe bones are all here,‚Äù he explains. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs all cosmetic work to make it feel like that Western, honky-tonk kind of space. It‚Äôs going to feel old and rustic, but not commercialized.‚Äù

The plan is to work with the modern farmhouse vibe that already exists in the white-brick and black-steel building. Design elements like reclaimed barn wood, corrugated metal, whiskey barrels, vintage milk cans and hay bales will play up the honky-tonk theme. To go with the hoedown atmosphere, there will be a menu of Southern fare that leans heavily into barbecue.

A wood-fired smoker¬†will turn out beef brisket, pork belly, burnt ends, pulled pork, pulled chicken and smoked sausage. Those items will be served Texas-style on large platters loaded with smoked meats, pickles, onions and bread. For those who prefer to skip the barbecue there are deviled eggs, fried pickles, BLTs starring house-smoked bacon, fried chicken and smash burgers. ‚ÄúAn ode to Shake Shack,‚Äù Dykstra says.

Of course, there will be plenty of whiskey and tequila to wash it all down.

The upper level will be home to a bar and stage for live music and line dances. There will be no food service up there, except for casual summer cookouts on the patio.

Dustin Dykstra isn‚Äôt the only ‚Äúdouble D‚Äù in the clan, he says, stating that both his mother and his son share the alliterative condition.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just meant to be fun, eye catching,‚Äù he says about the playful name.

Look for Double D‚Äôs Honky Tonk and Smokehouse to open in the coming weeks.

Subscribe to CLE Bites, Doug Trattner‚Äôs weekly food newsletter.

Follow us: Google News | NewsBreak | Reddit | Instagram | Facebook | Twitter

The post Double D‚Äôs Honky Tonk and Smokehouse to Open in Willoughby appeared first on Cleveland Scene.

title: Ohio Republican Lawmaker Wants Stiffer Penalties for Masked Offenders as Dems Ask, What About ICE?
description:
An Ohio Republican lawmaker has proposed a measure heightening penalties for people who commit crimes while concealing their identity with a mask or disguise. Ohio Democrats would like to see the same restrictions applied to law enforcement officers. State Rep. Josh Williams, R-Sylvania Township, has introduced Ohio¬†House Bill 236, which creates a new offense of […]

The post Ohio Republican Lawmaker Wants Stiffer Penalties for Masked Offenders as Dems Ask, What About ICE? appeared first on Cleveland Scene.
content:
An Ohio Republican lawmaker has proposed a measure heightening penalties for people who commit crimes while concealing their identity with a mask or disguise. Ohio Democrats would like to see the same restrictions applied to law enforcement officers.

State Rep. Josh Williams, R-Sylvania Township, has introduced Ohio¬†House Bill 236, which creates a new offense of ‚Äúmasked harassment‚Äù which is punishable as a first-degree misdemeanor.

The state‚Äôs aggravated riot statutes get new masking offenses as well. Wearing a mask while engaging in disorderly conduct with four or more individuals is a fifth-degree felony. Doing so with the intent of committing an act of violence would be a third-degree felony.

Additionally, Williams proposes a new sentencing specification for any felony committed by someone concealing their identity. If they‚Äôre found guilty, they‚Äôd face a one-year mandatory prison term.

‚ÄúIn recent years,‚Äù Williams told a House committee Wednesday, ‚Äúwe‚Äôve witnessed a troubling increase in individuals concealing their identities, often with masks, while engaging in harassment, trespass and violent crimes.‚Äù

‚ÄúIncreasing the penalties for wearing a mask while committing a crime,‚Äù he went on, ‚Äúclearly sends a message: concealment for the purpose of evading accountability will not be tolerated in our communities and in our state.‚Äù

Wearing a mask not only helps an offender evade punishment, Williams said, it ‚Äúintensifies the psychological terror‚Äù victims suffer.

He invoked protests outside a Los Angeles Synagogue and the assassination in Minnesota of a state lawmaker and her husband.

‚ÄúTogether we can reinforce the rule of law, protect our communities and ensure that no one can use anonymity as a shield for criminal behavior,‚Äù Williams insisted.

Democrats on the committee asked the question likely on the mind of anyone following President Trump‚Äôs immigration crackdown or the looming government shutdown over Department of Homeland Security funding: OK, what about ICE?

Goose meet gander

Starting last December, thousands of Department of Homeland Security officers, including Immigration and Customs Enforcement and Customs and Border Protection, descended on the Twin Cities.

Since then, the agency claims it has arrested 3,000 undocumented people. The operation has also led to the killing of two U.S. citizens.

The backlash has been swift and fierce. In addition to a shake up in the operation‚Äôs leadership, Congressional Democrats are threatening to hold up funding for DHS.

One of their central demands is prohibiting federal agents from carrying out their duty in masks.

‚ÄúI could not, you know, not think about ICE and federal law enforcement and what‚Äôs been happening over the last few months,‚Äù Ohio state Rep. Ismail Mohamed told Williams.

He explained Ohio Democrats have proposed legislation requiring all law enforcement officers, with limited exceptions, to identify themselves and not wear masks on duty.

‚ÄúSo, I guess would you be in favor of this applying to law enforcement as well?‚Äù Mohamed asked about Williams‚Äô proposal.

Williams said he would not be supportive of legislation that ‚Äúdictates‚Äù what federal law enforcement can and can‚Äôt do in the state.

He noted a mask ban in California was recently blocked in the courts because it exempts state police ‚Äî thereby discriminating against federal officers.

Mohamed asked about exceptions for individuals wearing a mask for safety or medical reasons.

Williams turned him down and pointed to Ohio‚Äôs gun possession sentencing specification.

‚ÄúIf a defendant comes in court and says, I didn‚Äôt plan on using the gun in the commission of crime, we said your possession of the gun is enough to get a one-year (sentence) specification here in the state of Ohio,‚Äù Williams said.

Who‚Äôs protected?

Some law enforcement officers in Ohio already hide their identity, Williams argued, and it‚Äôs important that they do so.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve seen gang units in my community conceal their identity. I‚Äôve seen undercover officers conceal their identity for purposes of investigative integrity. And what we‚Äôre seeing now is doxing federal immigration enforcement,‚Äù Williams said.

State Rep. Phil Plummer, R-Dayton, agreed it‚Äôs ‚Äúso important to mask these officers up.‚Äù

Before serving in the statehouse, Plummer was the Montgomery County Sheriff, and in that role, he oversaw several officers engaged in drug enforcement.

‚ÄúThese cartels threaten my officer‚Äôs lives. They threaten my officer‚Äôs children‚Äôs lives,‚Äù Plummer said.

‚ÄúWe all know I can Google anybody sitting in this room and find out where you live in two minutes, maybe a minute and a half, very simple. It‚Äôs all out there on the net.‚Äù

Ohio state Rep. Beryl Brown Piccolantonio, D-Gahanna, brushed those arguments off as red herrings.

The mask ban Ohio Democrats have proposed applies to local, state, and federal officers equally, and carries exceptions for masks worn for safety, by SWAT units or undercover officers.

She noted as well that Ohio law already grants sweeping protections to keep public safety officials‚Äô personal information out of public records.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm struggling to see why we would have, I guess, a different First Amendment right apply,‚Äù she said, when law enforcement officers receive protections that private citizens can‚Äôt access.

Williams rejected the idea that his bill creates different levels of constitutional rights, and he made another comparison to Ohio‚Äôs sentencing rules for gun possession.

‚ÄúIf you have a gun in your possession when you commit an offense, guess what? It‚Äôs a one-year weapon specification,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThat doesn‚Äôt mean it lowered your constitutional right to carry a gun.‚Äù

Speaking after the hearing, Williams acknowledged there was a time ‚Äî back when local governments worked with federal agencies and opponents weren‚Äôt ‚Äúdoxing elected officials‚Äù ‚Äî when it wouldn‚Äôt have been acceptable for law enforcement officers to conceal their identity in the line of duty.

‚ÄúNow, with the political climate that we have in the United States,‚Äù he said, ‚ÄúI think it is absolutely reasonable for law enforcement officers, such as ICE, to conceal their identities for the safety and security of those officers moving forward.‚Äù

Originally published by the Ohio Capital Journal. Republished here with permission.

The post Ohio Republican Lawmaker Wants Stiffer Penalties for Masked Offenders as Dems Ask, What About ICE? appeared first on Cleveland Scene.

title: Cleveland‚Äôs Adam Rich To Release New Solo Effort
description:
Local singer-songwriter Adam Rich will release his latest solo CD, Kiss Me I‚Äôm Rich, on Feb. 20 on his own Love Muffin Records. The title comes from a mug that Rich‚Äôs parents had bought at some point before he was born. He remembers growing up with the mug in the house and thought it would […]

The post Cleveland’s Adam Rich To Release New Solo Effort appeared first on Cleveland Scene.
content:
Local singer-songwriter Adam Rich will release his latest solo CD, Kiss Me I‚Äôm Rich, on Feb. 20 on his own Love Muffin Records.

The title comes from a mug that Rich‚Äôs parents had bought at some point before he was born. He remembers growing up with the mug in the house and thought it would make a great album title and cover photo. The album commences with the instrumental ‚ÄúKurtigo,‚Äù a track based on the time when his backing band‚Äôs drummer had vertigo, and locals such as Blue Antidote‚Äôs Ken Blaze, State of Being‚Äôs Chris Foldi, Shake Ground‚Äôs Ed Marthey and Cuyahoga Fails‚Äôs Bob Ignizio guest on the album.

The Cleveland Rocks Shop on Waterloo will be the sole location you can purchase it physically. Two dollars from every CD sold will be donated to the Gathering Place, a Cleveland cancer support center.

The label recently celebrated its 30th anniversary in 2024; it‚Äôll  host its second annual Super Awesome Concert showcase on Sunday, June 28, the Beachland Ballroom with Flowers Love Being Eerie, Craig Bell & the Dead Man‚Äôs Handle, Vulgar Devils, The Robert Conn Band and DJ Mimi Dromette.

title: Fall in Love with Cleveland: Date Night Ideas
description:
Cleveland knows how to set the stage for romance. From chef-driven dining experiences and sunsets over Lake Erie to strolls through vibrant neighborhoods, the city is overflowing with incredible date-night possibilities. Hand-in-hand with that special someone, explore eclectic streets, savor flavors that tell a story and uncover hidden gems that make The Land the ultimate […]

The post Fall in Love with Cleveland: Date Night Ideas appeared first on Cleveland Scene.
content:
Cleveland knows how to set the stage for romance. From chef-driven dining experiences and sunsets over Lake Erie to strolls through vibrant neighborhoods, the city is overflowing with incredible date-night possibilities. Hand-in-hand with that special someone, explore eclectic streets, savor flavors that tell a story and uncover hidden gems that make The Land the ultimate backdrop for L-O-V-E.

Here‚Äôs some inspiration to help you plan a date that feels both elevated and unforgettable.

Dinner Date

Westsiders promises refined romance vibes with a modern twist. Known for handcrafted cocktails, scratch-made pastas and seasonal dishes like salmon and scallops. 

‚ÄúYou‚Äôll see unique cocktails  you won‚Äôt find elsewhere‚Äù says Madison Berner, director of public relations for Local Hospitality Group. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a great spot whether you want the full dinner or just appetizers and drinks.‚Äù

The Rocky River favorite is a larger space but still feels private and intimate, offering three distinct areas: the lounge and bar is comfortable and relaxed, ideal for a first date or cocktails; the dining room is designed for a more traditional romantic dinner; and the garage area has low-top tables and sofa seating areas for a cozy feel. Reservations are recommended.

FIRST DATE TIP: Start with cocktails at the bar and, if sparks fly, stay for dinner. The bar is full-service and comfortable for a full meal.  19880 Detroit Road, Rocky River, 440-488-9908, westsiders.com

When you think of date night, barbecue might not be the first cuisine that comes to mind, but Landmark Smokehouse has been proving couples wrong for years. 

Landmark is known for its elevated barbecue, but what truly sets it apart is its exclusive bourbon collection. With 22 custom barrel picks ‚Äî including two house tequilas and 20 bourbons you won‚Äôt find anywhere else ‚Äî Landmark boasts one of the best bourbon selections in the city. For bourbon lovers, this is a date night destination that surprises and impresses.

With seating for about 56 guests, Landmark feels intimate yet lively. The new furniture and design create a comfortable, upscale environment where guests love to linger. Reservations are recommended, especially on weekends, as this spot is a go-to for birthdays, anniversaries and date nights. Reservations are highly recommended, especially on weekends, as this spot is a go-to for birthdays, anniversaries and date nights.

‚ÄúThe number of times I‚Äôve sent champagne to tables because it‚Äôs an anniversary or an engagement ‚Äî it‚Äôs definitely a date night spot,‚Äù says Cody Cammarn, general manager.  ‚ÄúBarbecue doesn‚Äôt usually scream romance, but for whatever reason, it works.‚Äù 11637 Clifton Blvd., Cleveland, 216-230-4040, landmarksmokehouse.com

If you‚Äôre aiming for a date night that feels like an occasion, STEAK in Tremont is a showstopper. This is where you add special notes and expect a few surprises along the way.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the main event,‚Äù says Julia Licastro, VP of Operations for Hangry Brands. ‚ÄúWe do custom menus for special events, and we try to create those wow moments ‚Äî because people want places they can tell stories about.‚Äù

From cocktails served in bathtubs with rubber duckies to hidden flasks tucked inside books, STEAK leans into playful luxury.

‚ÄúLike, oh my God, I ordered the build-your-own sundae and all my toppings came out on a ferris wheel,‚Äù Licastro laughs. ‚ÄúOr our carnival crab cakes ‚Äî they‚Äôre like corn dogs, but with crab cakes inside.‚Äù

Even the little details matter: The front door is a repurposed vintage meat cooler, the windows are blacked out for an immersive vibe and checks come with Hershey‚Äôs Kisses and temporary tattoos.

‚ÄúThose cheeky touches open up opportunities for conversation and laughter,‚Äù Licastro says. ‚ÄúEven if the date‚Äôs not going great, you can still share a giggle.‚Äù Reservations are recommended.12179 W. 11th St., Cleveland, 216-331-2724, steakcle.com

Sometimes date night calls for a casual stop in for a slice of pie, and Geraci‚Äôs Slice Shop delivers.

Located near Rocket Arena and Progressive Field, it‚Äôs the ultimate pre- or post-game hangout.

‚ÄúPerfect if you‚Äôre going to a Cavs or Monsters game and want to grab a quick bite,‚Äù says Julia Licastro, vice president of operations. 

The vibe is pure nostalgia: think ‚Äô80s pizzeria style with vintage decor, Pac-Man machines and a soundtrack of throwback hits.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs all about that big slice of pizza,‚Äù Licastro adds. ‚ÄúServed New York-style on paper plates. Grab a beer or cocktail in a cute little flask, or just take your slice to go and keep the night rolling.‚Äù603 Prospect Ave. E, Cleveland, 216-202-2775, geracisrestaurant.com

Have Fun Together

Sometimes the best way to connect is over creative cocktails, conversation and a little friendly competition. Enter Birdietown, Cleveland‚Äôs only indoor mini golf hotspot. 

Located in Lakewood‚Äôs Birdtown neighborhood, Birdietown is the manifestation of a date-night dream from owners Tim and Erin Frazee. ‚ÄúI literally have a brown paper napkin from Bar Cento in a frame where we sketched out a corner building with a corner entrance, and it looks remarkably like what we ended up with,‚Äù Erin recalls. ‚ÄúThat was 15 years ago.‚Äù

Birdietown more than delivers on that vision with a two-story, one-of-a-kind concept that includes stunning bars, a menu of delicious shareables and unique libations (try the FORE! Play) and two nine-hole courses (one on each level) ‚Äî all packaged in a sparkling, stylish atmosphere that feels special. 

‚ÄúWe love cozying up at a bar to have dinner,‚Äù Erin says. ‚ÄúSo it was important that we had beautiful bars. Upstairs, it‚Äôs lively and glowing with the chandelier. Downstairs, it‚Äôs much more loungey, like a speakeasy.‚Äù

In just a year since opening, Birdietown has become a little love nest, now a popular spot for blind dates, first dates, proposals and even couples stopping in for photos on their wedding day.

Mini-golf might be a winning icebreaker for a high-stakes first date: ‚ÄúYou have something to do with your hands,‚Äù Erin says with a laugh. ‚ÄúMy personal favorite is when people come in, have cocktails and play golf. It‚Äôs an activity, so it breaks the ice right away. You have a drink, then dinner, and if the night‚Äôs going well, you can go downstairs and play another nine holes.‚Äù

Happy hour makes Birdietown a great after-work meetup spot, and after 7 p.m. the space becomes strictly 21+, creating a true adults-only escape.12501 Madison Ave., Lakewood, birdietowncle.com


Want to take your date to the next level? Visit Cleveland Rocks Climbing in Ohio City, a striking venue nestled in the historic Ohio City Masonic Temple with rock walls and skylights that feels like a hidden wonder. The high-octane outing offers 18,000 square feet of climbing that is welcoming to both newcomers and seasoned pros.  2831 Franklin Blvd., Cleveland, 216-220-9894, clevelandrocksclimbing.org


How about a book crawl to explore Cleveland‚Äôs indie bookstores. Consider Loganberry Books on Larchmere, featuring themed rooms and floor-to-ceiling shelves, the ThirdSpace Reading Room in Glenville, which celebrates Black culture and hosts reading circles, and Visible Voice in Ohio City, now located in a stunning former theater with plans for live music and readings.  13015 Larchmere Blvd., Cleveland, 216-795-9800, loganberrybooks.com 1464 E. 105th St., Cleveland, 440-753-1275, thirdspacereadingroom.com 4601 Lorain Ave., Cleveland, 216-961-0084, visiblevoicebooks.com

Cheers to Romance

For sultry, sophisticated spirits to celebrate a special evening, head to Society Speakeasy in the heart of downtown on East Fourth Street. Hangry Brands acquired this Cleveland staple in April and turned up the speakeasy vibes to full volume.

‚ÄúWe even moved the entrance,‚Äù says Julia Licastro, vice president of operations, explains. ‚ÄúNow, when you walk downstairs, it looks like a maintenance room with hard hats and work orders. Then you enter through a broom closet lined with actual brooms and mops ‚Äî and suddenly you‚Äôre in this glamorous, cave-like bar with plush banquettes and bathtubs turned into tables.‚Äù

The crowd is strictly 21+, making it ideal for romantic evenings. The cocktail program ranges from adventurous craft creations to classics done perfectly.

‚ÄúIf you want the best espresso martini you‚Äôve ever had, we‚Äôve got that,‚Äù Licastro says. ‚ÄúBut if you‚Äôre feeling bold, we‚Äôve got experimental options too.‚Äù

Pair your drink with a snack tray of popcorn, nuts and pretzels ‚Äî or indulge in decadent desserts like gold-dusted chocolate mousse cake or rotating cheesecakes.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the perfect spot before or after dinner ‚Äî or for a nightcap after Playhouse Square,‚Äù Licastro adds. 2063 East Fourth Street, Cleveland, 216-930-2655, societycleveland.com

In the heart of downtown Lakewood, you‚Äôll find Humble Wine Bar.

If you‚Äôre looking for a date night that feels warm and inviting ‚Äî like a fine wine and bubbling wood-fired pizza ‚Äî Humble has glowing reviews as a date-night favorite. Tucked into Detroit‚Äôs streetscape in the heart of the city, Humble offers rustic charm, globally inspired flavors and an atmosphere that makes you want to linger whether it‚Äôs a romantic evening, a first date or a night out with friends.

‚ÄúWe want people to feel comfortable, whether they‚Äôre sharing small plates, sipping cocktails or just enjoying the vibe,‚Äù says Nick Deeb, who, along with Geoff Mathias, took ownership of Humble in May 2025. ‚ÄúHospitality is everything to us. We love taking care of people and creating a space where they can relax and connect.‚Äù

The bar seating is especially intimate. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre right in front of the pizza oven, so there‚Äôs this warmth and energy that makes the experience special,‚Äù he says.

Humble recently refreshed its menu with bold, global flavors sure to get the date-night buzzing. The wine list goes beyond the basics, featuring varietals like Nebbiolo, Trebbiano, Cabernet Franc and even a white Pinot Noir. The seasonal cocktail menu is equally creative, with options like a pancetta fat-washed whiskey and peach drink, an ube-infused egg white sour and a spiced pear daiquiri. Bourbon lovers will appreciate the curated selection featuring E.H. Taylor and Blanton‚Äôs. 

End the date with the Humble‚Äôs hit dessert cocktail: The Banana Fana Fo Fini, a banana espresso martini topped with a bruleed banana slice. ‚ÄúPeople love it,‚Äù Deeb says. 15400 Detroit Ave., Lakewood, 216-767-5977, humblewinebar.com

Tour a Neighborhood

Start with Poppy on Larchmere in the Greater Buckeye neighborhood. This charming restaurant offers a cozy, sit-down experience in a beautifully restored house, surrounded by walkable shops and galleries for exploring before or after dinner.  12502 Larchmere Blvd., Cleveland, 216-415-5069, poppycleveland.com

Cleveland‚Äôs 29 distinct and eclectic neighborhoods offer endless ways to make date night unforgettable. Thanks to the Love Cleveland Neighborhoods campaign from Cleveland Neighborhood Progress ‚Äî and stellar recommendations from the nonprofit‚Äôs marketing director, Josh Jones Forbes ‚Äî we‚Äôre shining a spotlight on some of the city‚Äôs most romantic, unique and unexpected destinations. 603 Prospect Ave. E., Cleveland, 216-202-2775, geracissliceshop.com

Another hidden gem is Doc‚Äôs on Harvard in the Lee-Harvard neighborhood. This intimate fine-dining spot has a fascinating backstory: It was once a neighborhood dentist‚Äôs office, now transformed into a warm, elegant restaurant. Chef-Owner Kolnita Riggins-Walker is known for her signature whitefish and decadent desserts like banana bread crumble. Reservations are a must. 16615 Harvard Ave., 216-751-0100, docsonharvard.com


Stroll through the Rockefeller Greenhouse in Glenville before dinner. It‚Äôs free, lush and full of tropical plants.  750 E. 88th St., Cleveland, 216-664-2512, rockefellerparkgreenhouse.org. Pair it with classic Italian in Little Italy at La Dolce Vita, where vegan-friendly options and Old-World charm make for a timeless date. Don‚Äôt skip Presti‚Äôs Bakery for coffee and cannoli afterward.  12112 Mayfield Road, 216-721-8155, ladolcevitacle.com

The post Fall in Love with Cleveland: Date Night Ideas appeared first on Cleveland Scene.

title: 4 Friend-Date Activities to Try This Winter
description:
There is no reason to spend Valentine‚Äôs Day or any of the wintery days of February alone. Call your friends and meet them indoors somewhere fun and entertaining.¬† Dips, Sips and More  Is there anything more decadent than a plump, juicy strawberry dipped in dark chocolate? But maybe you and your best friend would prefer […]

The post 4 Friend-Date Activities to Try This Winter appeared first on Cleveland Scene.
content:
There is no reason to spend Valentine‚Äôs Day or any of the wintery days of February alone. Call your friends and meet them indoors somewhere fun and entertaining.¬†

Dips, Sips and More 

Is there anything more decadent than a plump, juicy strawberry dipped in dark chocolate? But maybe you and your best friend would prefer dipping grapes, bananas or pineapples into melted chocolate. On Valentine‚Äôs Day, The Winery at Chateau Hough presents Dip & Sip, an activity that pairs three holiday favorites ‚Äî wine, chocolate and fruit. Two time slots (12:30 to 3 p.m. and 4 to 6:30 p.m.) are available with reservations.

Can‚Äôt make Valentine‚Äôs Day? ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs Make Wine,‚Äù on March 14, is perfect for a group of friends who use kits to explore the entire winemaking process and go home (after four sessions that extend into May) each with their own gallon of wine. Also, ‚ÄúSuds and Sips‚Äù is the winery‚Äôs soap making session on April 11.

The Winery at Chateau Hough was founded in 2019 and supports the nonprofit Neighborhood Solutions Inc. The winery‚Äôs manager, Brenda Frazier, urges friends to ‚Äúcome, have fun and meet people.‚Äù Also, wear clothes that you don‚Äôt mind getting a little rose wine on if you do ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs Make Wine.‚Äù Participants can get pretty enthusiastic, warns Frazier.1650 E. 66th St., 216-438-0964, chateauhough.com; use exploretock.com for reservations¬† ¬†

Roll it Out     

‚ÄúPeople don‚Äôt just want something to do, they want something to remember,‚Äù says RollHouse Entertainment‚Äôs Chef Marketing Officer Phil Carpenter. That means tons of laughs and a menu stacked with casual favorites, including smash burgers, sliders, pizza and craft cocktails. With locations in Solon, Mentor and North Olmsted, RollHouse offers ‚Äúhigh-energy experiences including Cosmic Bowling, escape rooms and a great arcade,‚Äù says Carpenter.    

‚ÄúRollHouse is a place to celebrate the people you love spending time with. It‚Äôs where fun lives,‚Äù he says.

Valentine‚Äôs Day reservations are available online.7300 Palisades Parkway, Mentor, mentor@therollhouse.com; 24488 Lorain Road, North Olmsted, northolmsted@therollhouse.com; 33185 Bainbridge Road, Solon, solon@therollhouse.com

Build Your Own Candle 

Maybe you and your bestie would enjoy a visit to The Cleveland Candle Company in Ohio City, where you can breathe in any of the amazing 150 to 200+ scents that can be chosen to create a custom candle. 

David Gin, a partner at The Cleveland Candle Company, recommends Rose Petals, Sacred Sandalwood and Cabernet Sauvignon. But about 30 choices of candle jars are also available. Still, Gin says he‚Äôd ‚Äúprobably go‚Äù with the Vintage Glass options or the Colored Ceramic jars for a February 14 creation.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the adventure of smelling through our vast scent collection and having the shared experience that makes every candle-making session so satisfying,‚Äù says Gin. ‚ÄúEvery time you light the candle you made, it brings back the memory of who you were with.‚Äù2032 West 25th St., 216-471-8477, clecandleco.com¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬†

Visit an Urban Winery 

CLE Urban Winery is known for its many and varied top-notch activities, educational events and entertainment. This month is certainly no exception at the working winery and tasting room. 

A Valentine‚Äôs Wine Flight and Food Pairing experience will be offered that holiday weekend along with live jazz performances on the 13th (7 to 9 p.m.) and 15th (6 to 8 p.m.). (Advance tickets for the wine tasting and food pairing available on Eventbrite; a limited number of tickets available for walk-ins.)

The Cleveland Heights winery provides a relaxed environment for besties and buddies to learn more about Ohio-made wine and enjoy time together. (How can anyone pass on a specialty wine called Hopped in the Heights?) But if you choose to abstain that is ok, too.

‚ÄúIn addition to a full bar, we have non-alcoholic beer, wine, cider and spirits for delightful mocktails,‚Äù says owner Destiny Burns. ‚ÄúWe also offer premium Italian sparkling sodas and other soft drinks.‚Äù 2180 Lee Road, 216-417-8313, cleurbanwinery.com

The post 4 Friend-Date Activities to Try This Winter appeared first on Cleveland Scene.

title: Discover Local Valentine‚Äôs Gifts Your Partner Will Actually Love
description:
Cleveland has a wealth of creative bakers, candy makers, florists, jewelry designers and others who can help make you look like the best gift giver ever. Meet several:    All City Candy ‚ÄúHeart-shaped candy is my favorite candy. (It‚Äôs) made with love and truly makes my heart full. It‚Äôs timeless, joyful and instantly brings a […]

The post Discover Local Valentine‚Äôs Gifts Your Partner Will Actually Love appeared first on Cleveland Scene.
content:
Cleveland has a wealth of creative bakers, candy makers, florists, jewelry designers and others who can help make you look like the best gift giver ever. Meet several:   

All City Candy

‚ÄúHeart-shaped candy is my favorite candy. (It‚Äôs) made with love and truly makes my heart full. It‚Äôs timeless, joyful and instantly brings a smile,‚Äù says Elisabeth Sapell, founder and president of All City Candy in Richmond Heights. ‚ÄúMy favorite conversation heart saying over the years has always been, ‚ÄòYou‚Äôre sweet,‚Äô which feels especially appropriate for a candy lady.‚Äù

But the ‚Äúpremium chocolates from the fine chocolate cases are always a great hit for Valentine‚Äôs Day ‚Äî they are beautiful, indulgent and meant to be shared,‚Äù according to Sapell. She also suggests a bouquet of chocolate roses, ‚Äúwhich lasts a little longer than the real thing,‚Äù and the hand-dipped strawberries that are made only twice a year (Valentine‚Äôs Day and Mother‚Äôs Day). 

Sapell, a lifelong chocolate lover, opened her family business in 2013. She now sells an endless variety of candy at her retail location (curbside pickup is also offered) and online. That includes cinnamon jelly hearts, cherry-flavored lollipops and milk chocolate marshmallow hearts. She also loves to make gifts combos ‚Äúthat feel thoughtful, nostalgic and fun‚Äù and suggests:

‚Ä¢ $25 to $40 ‚Äì a sweet mix of conversation hearts, retro Valentine candy, gourmet chocolate bars and seasonal treats

‚Ä¢ $50 to $75 ‚Äì Valentine gift box with chocolate-covered pretzels, caramels and premium chocolates

‚Ä¢ $100 ‚Äì deluxe gift assortment with premier chocolates, chocolate-dipped Oreos, nostalgic favorites and seasonal Valentine treats.746 Richmond Road, Richmond Heights, 216-487-7070, allcitycandy.com

The Urban Orchid 

Expect the unexpected if you order a Valentine‚Äôs Day floral arrangement from The Urban Orchid. ‚ÄúWe try to make every flower arrangement specific. You can‚Äôt just say, ‚ÄòI want the Have-a-Nice-Day bouquet.‚Äô We ask about the person you are sending it to, maybe their favorite colors, style, flowers,‚Äù explains owner and designer Brandon Sitler, whose shops are in Tremont and Ohio City/Hingetown. ‚ÄúOf course, you can‚Äôt wait too long to order or some things may be gone.‚Äù

Sitler incorporates lots of ‚Äúbright and cheery, vibrant jewel tones‚Äù into his floral creations. But more February 14 traditional colors are also available, of course. Winter designs may feature roses, peonies, hydrangeas and orchids, plus a surprise or two with an unusual choice of vegetation not often seen in creations.   

‚ÄúOur clients are looking for that Urban Orchid design, look and feel,‚Äù says Sitler.  ‚ÄúThat means super textured and unique.‚Äù

Sitler teaches floral design classes and holds events at the Tremont location, while Ohio City is more of a walk-in shop. But each sells gift baskets, locally made candles, chocolates, indoor plants, containers and Cleveland-themed items.

The designer has two suggestions. Don‚Äôt limit fresh flowers to just the living or dining rooms. They are beautiful in any room. And if you put them in a bathroom, they‚Äôll love the moisture in the air from the shower. Also, don‚Äôt forget to add water to any container and/or replace it with fresh, clean water no matter where it is displayed. 

‚ÄúThe flowers will last longer,‚Äù he says.
Tremont Design Studio, 3154 W. 14th St., 216-785-3618; Ohio City/Hingetown, 1455 W. 29th St., 216-589-0788; theurbanorchid.com

Sweet Bean 

Sweet Bean, a chocolate studio and shop in Cleveland‚Äôs Collinwood neighborhood, opened in February 2021. If all goes according to schedule, owner and founder Kristin Barnes will be in her new spot this February, only four blocks away. The move from just under 1,000 square feet to 3,000 square feet will allow expansion for larger and more frequent tasting classes and other events. (Barnes may temporarily operate both locations until the move is settled.)

For an extraordinary Valentine‚Äôs Day gift, Barnes invites shoppers to ‚Äúbuild a box of hand-painted bonbons,‚Äù the chocolates she calls the ‚Äúrock stars‚Äù of her business and which have brought her local fame. 

‚ÄúSome people call them jewels, crystals, planets, bowling balls. The bonbons are shiny and bright and our tagline is that they are almost too pretty to eat,‚Äù says Barnes, who began making fine chocolates in 2013. ‚ÄúThe most popular assortment is the nine-piece gift box. You can find Sweet Bean chocolates at some other locations across the city, but those are pre-mixed. If you come in and build a box yourself, that‚Äôs part of the excitement.‚Äù

Barnes says what sets her chocolate apart from ‚Äúgrocery store chocolate‚Äù is her product‚Äôs ‚Äúreally high cocoa butter content which makes it decadent and luscious.‚Äù  One or two pieces is all someone needs to feel full and satisfied ‚Äî it‚Äôs not like eating handfuls of M&M‚Äôs, she says. Usually, 24 painted bonbon varieties are available at any one time in the shop. But do think about Hazelnut (Barnes‚Äô personal favorite), Salted Caramel, Brownie Batter and one the chocolatier said is coming on strong ‚Äî Mexican Hot Cocoa. present location: 819 E. 185th St.; new location: 701 E. 185th St.; 216-795-5561; sweetbeancandies.com 

Mishi Lifestyle 

Tracy Burnett is founder and owner of Mishi Lifestyle in Lakewood. The home d√©cor and gift store opened in 2021 and is a soothing source for those who wish to surround themselves with objects that evoke tranquility. That includes furniture, home and body scents, jewelry, barware and pet items.

‚ÄúPeople are naturally made for connection, belonging and closeness,‚Äù says Burnett. ‚ÄúLove, in all its forms, gives life meaning. But peace and serenity create the space to truly feel and receive that love.‚Äù      

If someone is looking for a gift that shows they care or one that makes the recipient know they are loved, Mishi Lifestyle is the place. One of Burnett‚Äôs favorite items is a mug with the words, ‚ÄúI Wish you Lived Next Door.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a beautiful reminder to a friend or family member that they are missed and loved every time they use it,‚Äù says Burnett. ‚ÄúWe sell many of these locally in our shop, but we also have shipped them to loved ones all over the country.‚Äù  

Burnett also suggests the Mishi Lifestyle Amber Grove Candle ‚Äúthat really sets the stage for a romantic moment.‚Äù Think a combination of Egyptian Amber, Himalayan Bamboo and Caribbean Teakwood scents. The soy candle has a 55-hour burn time and is sold in a matte black glass vessel.15602 Detroit Ave., Lakewood, 216-304-3832; mishilifestyle.com

Oc√©anne                                

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a heart, but it‚Äôs something you can wear all year,‚Äù says Anne Harrill, Oc√©anne owner and designer, describing her brass-casted Verona Signet Ring. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs classic, one of our best sellers and now we can offer engraving.‚Äù 

French native Harrill owns three Northeast Ohio jewelry and gift stores, in addition to her online business. Her minimalist, but sophisticated and sometimes whimsical, jewelry designs have made her original work a favorite across generations. Even though she spotlights the heart ring, Harrill says the symbol doesn‚Äôt have to be incorporated into jewelry given for February 14. It‚Äôs more important that jewelry is selected with the recipient‚Äôs taste in mind and not the giver‚Äôs, she says. 

Also, for that extra special Valentine‚Äôs Day experience, consider Oceanne‚Äôs Forever Jewelry. The recipient chooses a chain at the store, the wrist is measured, a little ring is added and then the clasp-less bracelet is welded closed, to be worn 24/7.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a very meaningful experience. We have had couples, mother and daughters, BFFs, bridal parties and three generations make appointments. And it‚Äôs affordable. You can choose from several chains, from gold filled to and sterling silver,‚Äù says Harrill, adding that if the piece must be removed for whatever reason, it can simply be cut and later a new ring can be attached if desired.   

Oc√©anne also offers about 40 different chains and charms in-store including: Heart Padlock, Moon and Star Pearl Charm, Gold Daisy, Evil Eye, Snake, Bee, Four-leaf Clover, Zodiac Signs, Coffee Cup, Fish and more. Crocker Park: 295 Main St., Westlake, 216-802-9981; Pinecrest: 411 Park Ave., Suite 137, Orange, 216-778-9268; Gordon Square: 6519 Detroit Ave., 216-862-7043; oceanne.net

The post Discover Local Valentine‚Äôs Gifts Your Partner Will Actually Love appeared first on Cleveland Scene.

title: Single? Cleveland Nights that Beat Swiping
description:
February might feel a little frosty for singles, with lovebirds flocking to romantic spots all over town. But forget hiding behind dating apps, Cleveland‚Äôs packed with ways to play, whether you‚Äôre flying solo or rolling deep with friends. Immerse Yourself in Culture  Mingle among the world‚Äôs most treasured artifacts at the coolest social mixer in […]

The post Single? Cleveland Nights that Beat Swiping appeared first on Cleveland Scene.
content:
February might feel a little frosty for singles, with lovebirds flocking to romantic spots all over town. But forget hiding behind dating apps, Cleveland‚Äôs packed with ways to play, whether you‚Äôre flying solo or rolling deep with friends.

Immerse Yourself in Culture 

Mingle among the world‚Äôs most treasured artifacts at the coolest social mixer in town: MIX at the Cleveland Museum of Art. This monthly event combines art, music and cocktails for an unforgettable night in one of Cleveland‚Äôs most iconic spaces. Each MIX has a unique theme, so expect something fresh every time. For February, the theme is Peace, Love & Soul celebrating black history month and Cleveland‚Äôs historic funk, soul and R&B themes. This is a ticketed event and can be purchased on the museum‚Äôs website at: clevelandart.org/events/mix-peace-love-and-soul.11150 East Blvd., Cleveland, 216-421-7350, clevelandart.org

Have Some No Judgment Fun 

Voted Best LGBT Bar eight years running, Twist Social Club is the ultimate singles destination. ‚ÄúThis isn‚Äôt a date night; it‚Äôs where you go to find a date,‚Äù says General Manager Cody Cammarn. With DJs every weekend, theme parties, karaoke, trivia and drag shows, Twist is all about energy, connection and inclusion.

‚ÄúWe want everyone to feel welcome at Twist,‚Äù says Cammarn. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not targeting any one specific letter in an acronym. It doesn‚Äôt matter if you‚Äôre in the community, if you‚Äôre straight, gay, bi, transsexual ‚Äî it does not matter to us. We want everyone to feel welcome at Twist.‚Äù

Whether you come solo or with friends, expect a packed dance floor, laser lights, and DJs spinning every Friday and Saturday night starting at 10 PM. The party goes strong until 2:30 AM every day of the week.11633 Clifton Blvd., Cleveland, 216-221-2333, twistsocialclub.com

Meet Someone ‚Äî or Someones 

Ready to ditch the endless swiping and meet real people in real time? You can find speed dating pop-up events throughout the city. They‚Äôre a structured and engaging way to meet multiple people in one night, minus the pressure of awkward first dates. Cleveland Speed Dating brings singles together every month for age-targeted events. Whether you‚Äôre in your 20s, 30s, 40s, or beyond, you‚Äôll rotate through some of the city‚Äôs best restaurants and chat one-on-one with 6 to 12 (sometimes more!) singles in a series of six-minute ‚ÄúPre-Dates.‚Äù After each mini-date, you simply mark who you‚Äôd like to see again, and you‚Äôll get your matches emailed to you within 24 hours.clevelandspeeddating.com

Tell Your Own Story 

Feeling creative? Step into Story Wars ‚Äî a monthly mashup of quirky prompts and quick-fire imagination at Jukebox in Ohio City. Over three rounds, you‚Äôll get offbeat prompts, craft your masterpiece in minutes, and (if you‚Äôre feeling bold) share it with the crowd. You can pen a story, choreograph a dance or even belt out a song. It‚Äôs the ultimate way to shake off self-doubt, break out of your comfort zone and maybe even start writing your own love story ‚Äî Cleveland style.1404 W. 29th St., Cleveland, 216-206-7699, jukeboxcle.com

The post Single? Cleveland Nights that Beat Swiping appeared first on Cleveland Scene.

title: Ohio Democratic Governor Candidate Amy Acton Makes Pitch for Addressing Health Care Costs
description:
Ohio Democratic candidate for governor Dr. Amy Acton said Tuesday that she‚Äôll bring a whole-of-government approach to dealing with rising health care costs if she‚Äôs elected. She also took Republican frontrunner to task over past comments about health care programs. Rising costs, declining coverage The physician and former state health department director said ‚Äúeverywhere I […]

The post Ohio Democratic Governor Candidate Amy Acton Makes Pitch for Addressing Health Care Costs appeared first on Cleveland Scene.
content:
Ohio Democratic candidate for governor Dr. Amy Acton said Tuesday that she‚Äôll bring a whole-of-government approach to dealing with rising health care costs if she‚Äôs elected.

She also took Republican frontrunner to task over past comments about health care programs.

Rising costs, declining coverage

The physician and former state health department director said ‚Äúeverywhere I go, people are talking about the cost of everyday life. Ninety five percent of what I‚Äôm hearing is not controversial at all.‚Äù

Housing, child care, electric bills, and property taxes ‚Äî Acton has heard voters complain about all of them.

‚ÄúBut the number one thing I am hearing about, and data is now showing this, it‚Äôs the rising cost of health care that is really putting people over the edge,‚Äù she said.

As part of the One Big Beautiful Bill, signed by President Trump last summer, people looking for health insurance on Affordable Care Act Marketplaces stopped receiving an enhanced subsidy to help cover premiums.

At the end of open enrollment last month, Ohio saw a 20% decline in Marketplace enrollment.

On a percentage basis, the Ohio Academy of Family Physicians noted, that was the second biggest decline in the country.

‚ÄúThink about that for a second,‚Äù Acton said. ‚ÄúWe know people are just saying I have to go without health care in order to pay my housing costs that are going up, my electric bill, my childcare bill, they‚Äôre just going without insurance, and whole families are going without. That is a big concern.‚Äù

But Acton acknowledged there‚Äôs a limit on what she, or any state leader, can do to bridge the gap.

She brought up Medicaid waivers or tax credits for people caring for loved ones as two examples.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll be looking at all the different levers a governor can pull,‚Äù Acton said, ‚Äúbut it‚Äôs going to have to be in partnership with our federal government.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs so much you can do right now on medical bankruptcy and on prescription drug costs,‚Äù Acton‚Äôs running mate David Pepper said.

‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt solve it all,‚Äù he continued, ‚Äúbut trying to make the premiums maybe a little more affordable, so 20% don‚Äôt drop off ‚Äî that‚Äôs happening all over. It‚Äôs just not happening in Ohio.‚Äù

Mistakes were made

Acton and Pepper also called out Ohio Republican governor candidate Vivek Ramaswamy for calling Medicare and Medicaid a mistake.

During an appearance on the Ezra Klein podcast in October 2024, Ramaswamy argued there are competing visions within the Republican party for what the ‚ÄúAmerica First‚Äù agenda actually means.

On the one hand, he said, there are those who want to use government power to protect or advance American economic interests and on the other ‚Äî the one Ramaswamy aligns with ‚Äî there are Republicans who see the project as ‚Äúdismantling the existence of that nanny state in all of its forms.‚Äù

In response, Klein asked Ramaswamy point blank if he thought Medicare and Medicaid were mistakes.

‚ÄúI believe they were, with the benefit of retrospect,‚Äù Ramaswamy said. ‚ÄúParticularly Medicaid, particularly the welfare state without work attachments required attached to it.‚Äù

More than 3 million Ohioans ‚Äî roughly a quarter of the state‚Äôs population ‚Äî are enrolled in Medicaid, according to research from the Kaiser Family Foundation.

Within that population, 72% of enrollees are already working.

Two and a half million Ohioans are enrolled in Medicare, which primarily covers the elderly, but there‚Äôs some overlap between the two programs.

About 400,000 Ohioans on Medicare receive assistance through Medicaid.

Jan Lanier, a registered nurse from Westerville, spoke about her family‚Äôs experience with Medicaid at Acton‚Äôs event.

Lanier explained her youngest granddaughter was born premature with severe disabilities.

Lanier‚Äôs daughter had a job and insurance but lost both because she had to take care of her child.

‚ÄúThe experience brought all of us into the world of Medicaid, waivers, and wait lists,‚Äù Lanier explained.

At 23, her granddaughter still lives with her daughter and they rely on Medicaid to cover the cost of caregivers and medical supplies.

‚ÄúI do not expect people running for office to be able to understand all the programs and services that come under their purview,‚Äù Lanier said.

‚ÄúI do, however, expect them to listen, and to make a serious effort to learn, before dismissively calling something that is the backbone of Ohio‚Äôs health care system a ‚Äòmistake.‚Äô‚Äù

Ramaswamy‚Äôs response

In an emailed statement, Ramaswamy‚Äôs campaign spokesperson Connie Luck said Acton‚Äôs ‚Äúfar-left approach would drive up health care costs and everyday expenses for all Ohioans, while suppressing take-home pay and economic growth. By contrast, Vivek‚Äôs vision for Ohio focuses on real reforms to deliver lower costs and bigger paychecks, not empty promises and government takeovers.‚Äù

As for Ramaswamy‚Äôs ‚Äòmistake‚Äô comment, Luck accused Acton of cherry-picking soundbites and called the attacks ‚Äúblatantly dishonest.‚Äù

Luck said Medicaid is a ‚Äúvital program,‚Äù but insisted it should work better for recipients and taxpayers.

‚ÄúVivek believes Ohioans deserve a Medicaid system that delivers stronger results than what we have seen over the past six decades, including basic work requirements for those who are able,‚Äù Luck said. ‚ÄúThat position is not extreme, it‚Äôs common sense.‚Äù

President Trump‚Äôs signature domestic policy bill includes national work requirement provisions for Medicaid recipients.

Starting next year enrollees nationwide will have to start reporting their employment status at least every six months.

That change will have a big impact on the bottom line.

The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office estimates work requirements alone will reduce Medicaid spending by $326 billion over the next decade, but those savings come with a cost.

Analyzing an earlier version of the bill, CBO forecasters suggested the policy would leave 4.8 million Americans without insurance by 2034.

A 2022 CBO report found state-level work requirements cost thousands of workers their coverage, ‚Äúand they appear to have little effect on employment.‚Äù

Originally published by the Ohio Capital Journal. Republished here with permission.

The post Ohio Democratic Governor Candidate Amy Acton Makes Pitch for Addressing Health Care Costs appeared first on Cleveland Scene.

title: Eyeing Easy Re-election, Chris Ronayne Promises Growth for Cuyahoga County in Second Term
description:
When Chris Ronayne took over the county executive seat in 2023, he did so with an eye on change. Armond Budish, Ronayne‚Äôs predecessor, had left an office littered with controversy after his two terms. Ronayne seized on a mesage of in with a new Cuyahoga and out with the old and ran with it. He […]

The post Eyeing Easy Re-election, Chris Ronayne Promises Growth for Cuyahoga County in Second Term appeared first on Cleveland Scene.
content:
When Chris Ronayne took over the county executive seat in 2023, he did so with an eye on change.

Armond Budish, Ronayne‚Äôs predecessor, had left an office littered with controversy after his two terms.

Ronayne seized on a mesage of in with a new Cuyahoga and out with the old and ran with it. He won both the primary and the general election that year by 30 percentage points.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what the voters kind of voted to reform,‚Äù Ronayne told Scene from a conference room at the County Building on Wednesday. ‚ÄúSo, we are continuing to be the reform candidate in the reform government.‚Äù

Ronayne is 57 and currently vying for a second term as Cuyahoga County executive, a role leading a region of 1.2 million people and 59 municipalities. As of mid-February, his candidacy is uncontested; he practically will be handed the county‚Äôs foremost seat come November.

It‚Äôs an opportunity Ronayne approaches with excitement. He envisions it as a kind of sequel to a laundry list of accomplishments he listed off from his first term. Successes marked by an pointed expansion of government. In 2023, he opened up the county‚Äôs Welcome Center for incoming immigrants; he created the Child Wellness Campus in 2024 to give kids more access to mental health care; the new Office of Violence Prevention, meant to tackle illegal guns, opened up last year.

And it‚Äôs likely Ronayne will champion that same growth energy come 2027, if everything goes as planned. He‚Äôll oversee the construction of the new county jail in Garfield Heights, potential groundbreaking of a remaking of the lakefront and riverfront; trees and pathways sprouting at Irishtown Bend; new music festivals and parks; new bus lanes, bike lanes and highway extensions; new uses for a dwindling Burke Lakefront Airport. (Ronayne‚Äôs fingers crossed.)

But nothing may better represent Ronayne‚Äôs hunger for growth, and his hyper-focused view of county government, than the $1 billion county jail, funded mostly by a sales tax extension, set to break ground this spring in Garfield Heights. It‚Äôs the largest project in recent Cuyahoga County history.

And it involves two of Ronayne‚Äôs latest dissenters. Earlier this year, County Prosecutor Michael O‚ÄôMalley rebuked Ronayne for ‚Äúillegally‚Äù handling County Sheriff Harold Pretel‚Äôs payroll, going as far as to threaten a lawsuit. (Pretel wants to control officer pay himself.) Cuyahoga is the only county in the state wherein its sheriff is not elected but assigned by its executive.

Ronayne found it yet another relic of the ‚Äúold boys‚Äù club. He would rather, he said, spend time on progress, on rethinking part of the criminal justice system in the county.

‚ÄúThis is an ecosystem, a justice ecosystem,‚Äù Ronayne said, about the complex. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt wake up out of bed and say, ‚ÄòGee, I‚Äôm happy to be building a new jail.‚Äô I‚Äôm only happy in as much as I will be building a more humane space.‚Äù

And a space where those awaiting trial or a plea can make use of their time locked up. Like, Ronayne suggested, earning a certificate at a partnering Tri-C program.

‚ÄúLook, if your in with us for 30 days,‚Äù he said, ‚Äúyou ought to come out with some kind of skill that you can bring to the outside world.‚Äù

But will Ronayne‚Äôs character and itch for growth continue to warm other members of the bureaucracy? After all, the county executive‚Äôs sparred often in the past three years with County Council over a range of issues‚Äîfrom the jurisdiction of the formerly-named Downtown Safety Patrol to what extent county taxpayer funds should be used to keep Downtown clean.

And also to what extent he should be buddying up with Mayor Bibb to actualize plans that he needs Bibb to follow through on. The obvious ones come to mind: How to reimagine the lakefront in a post-Browns world. And what to do with Burke.

And there‚Äôs finally creating a county Music Commission, akin to Nashville‚Äôs or Austin’s. There‚Äôs expanding the county transit-oriented development loan program and funding housing near transit stops. There‚Äôs better utilizing brownfield land, building dedicated bus lanes or making sure people know they have unclaimed funds the state is using to build the new Browns stadium in Brook Park.

‚ÄúThe overall objective in the next term is to lay out a blueprint for growth and work that plan,‚Äù Ronayne told Scene. Despite still losing a half percent of its population per year. ‚ÄúWe need to stop that population loss and turn that corner toward population growth.‚Äù 

Or at least convince the people he’s trying to reverse a decades-long trend.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve fought good fights. Some we win, some we lose,‚Äù Ronayne said. ‚ÄúBut I can always look at myself in the mirror and saying I‚Äôm fighting for the people.‚Äù

‚ÄúDo you feel like after all this time you‚Äôve helped restore trust in this seat?‚Äù Scene asked.

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù Ronayne said. He smiled. ‚ÄúAnd I think that‚Äôs reflected in not having an opponent‚Äù in this race.
